titleInfo.title: William F. Tunnard carriage and harness factory ambrotype, circa 1855

mods.abstract: This ambrotype shows the three-story brick building of the William F. Tunnard carriage and harness factory, located on the corner of Main and Church streets in Baton Rouge, La. William F. Tunnard (1809-1871) was a native of New York and, by the 1830s, a coach maker in Newark, N. J. By 1842, he and his family were living in Louisiana. In 1845 he purchased a lot on the corner of Church and Main streets in Baton Rouge where he built his carriage and harness factory, a site dominated today by St. Joseph Cathedral. Tunnard served as a Confederate Major in the Civil War. He is buried in Magnolia Cemetery.

titleInfo.title: Historic Images of Baton Rouge from LSU Libraries

mods.accessCondition: Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Copyright of the original material is retained in accordance with U.S. copyright laws.

mods.note: William F. Tunnard Carriage and Harness Factory Ambrotype, Mss. 4959, Louisiana and Lower Mississippi Valley Collections, LSU Libraries, Baton Rouge, La.
